journal-meta.journal-title: Human Factors: The Journal of Human Factors and Ergonomics Society

subj-group.subject: Special Section: Keynote Addresses From the 18th Triennial Congress of the International Ergonomics Association

title-group.article-title: A Review of Human Factors Challenges of Complex Adaptive Systems
title-group.subtitle: Discovering and Understanding Chaos in Human Performance

author-notes.corresp: Waldemar Karwowski, Department of Industrial Engineering and Management Systems, University of Central Florida, 4000 Central Florida Blvd., P.O. Box 162993, Orlando, FL 32816-2993; e-mail: wkar@ucf.edu.

article-meta.issue-title: Special Section: Keynote Addresses From the 18th Triennial Congress of the International Ergonomics Association

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: In this paper, the author explores a need for a greater understanding of the true nature of human–system interactions from the perspective of the theory of complex adaptive systems, including the essence of complexity, emergent properties of system behavior, nonlinear systems dynamics, and deterministic chaos.

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Human performance, more often than not, constitutes complex adaptive phenomena with emergent properties that exhibit nonlinear dynamical (chaotic) behaviors.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: The complexity challenges in the design and management of contemporary work systems, including service systems, are explored. Examples of selected applications of the concepts of nonlinear dynamics to the study of human physical performance are provided.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Understanding and applications of the concepts of theory of complex adaptive and dynamical systems should significantly improve the effectiveness of human-centered design efforts of a large system of systems.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Performance of many contemporary work systems and environments may be sensitive to the initial conditions and may exhibit dynamic nonlinear properties and chaotic system behaviors. Human-centered design of emergent human–system interactions requires application of the theories of nonlinear dynamics and complex adaptive system.

sec.title: Application:
sec.p: The success of future human–systems integration efforts requires the fusion of paradigms, knowledge, design principles, and methodologies of human factors and ergonomics with those of the science of complex adaptive systems as well as modern systems engineering.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The premise of the human factors and ergonomics (HFE) discipline is the systematic use of the knowledge concerning relevant human characteristics to achieve compatibility in the design of interactive systems of people, machines, environments, and devices of all kinds to ensure specific goals (Human Factors and Ergonomics Society, 2012). As such, HFE also focuses on the understanding of the nature of human–system interactions, viewed from the unified perspective of the science, engineering, design, technology, and management of human-compatible systems (Karwowski, 2005), which is critical to fulfilling its premise. Recently, Dul et al. (2012) presented a compelling and robust international strategy for the HFE community to strengthen demand and application of high-quality HFE, emphasizing its key elements: systems approach, design-driven principles, and performance and well-being goals.

The traditional approach to human-centered design paradigm and work redesign efforts requires an extensive (if not complete) knowledge of interactions between its components and the overall system behavior (see, for example, requirements for ergonomics task analysis). Contrary to such requirements, many of the systems under consideration by HFE studies exhibit complex behaviors that are often dynamic, emerging out of the complexity of the large number of either relatively simple and often fuzzy rules that drive the system or interdependent interactions between system components. For example, several recent studies demonstrated that application of neuro-fuzzy modeling techniques allowed for estimating time domain electromyographic responses of trunk muscles to manual lifting in limited task conditions (Davis et al., 2008; Hou, Zurada, Karwowski, Marras, & Davis, 2007; Karwowski et al., 2006). Furthermore, behaviors of complex human–machine systems may be very sensitive to small changes in the initial task (performance) conditions leading to nonlinear, and therefore, often unpredictable—that is, emergent—system responses. Recently, Walker, Stanton, Salmon, Jenkins, and Rafferty (2010) have discussed how selected concepts of complex adaptive systems can be translated and applied in general to the field of HFE.

In this article, I explore a need for a greater understanding of the true nature of human–system interactions from the perspective of theory of complex adaptive systems and nonlinear dynamics, including the essence of system complexity, emergent properties of system behavior, nonlinear systems dynamics, and deterministic chaos (Bar-yam, 2004; Cilliers, 1998; Erdi, 2010; Gros, 2008; Kaplan & Glass, 1995). I also discuss the scaling of HFE problem domains in the context of systems of systems. Finally, examples of selected applications of nonlinear dynamics to the study of human physical performance are provided.

sec.title: Expanding HFE Scope: Complex Systems Design
sec.p: Over the years, the HFE discipline has been expanding its scope beyond traditional HFE areas of physical ergonomics, psycho-physiological ergonomics, cognitive ergonomics, and organizational (or macro) ergonomics toward more systems-oriented ergonomics, reflecting the increasing complexity and uncertainty (fuzziness) of the relevant human–system interactions (Hancock, Masalonis, & Parasuraman, 2000; Karwowski, 1991, 1992a, 1992b, 1993, 1997, 2000; Salvendy, 2012). Examples of this general trend toward human-centered design of more complex systems include the new domains of nanoergonomics and neuroergonomics (Karwowski, 2005; Parasuraman & Rizzo, 2007). It should be noted that this scaling out of the HFE discipline theory and its applications has rapidly accelerated in the recent years, with the focus on a very large system, that is, a system of systems, as well as a variety of other complex adaptive systems.

Traditional areas of human-centered design applications include a variety of domains of human performance and human–system interactions, such as industrial infrastructure, manufacturing processes, transportation, urban development, or design of consumer products. In the past 15 years, there has also been a marked shift toward human-centered design of large service systems. The contemporary service industry, which includes, among others, insurance and financial sectors, transportation systems, energy systems, urban government, education hospitality systems, health care systems, and the entertainment industry, accounts today for more than 80% of employment in the United States (Maglio & Spohrer, 2007; Salvendy & Karwowski, 2010). These changes pose new challenges for the human-centered design of such systems and call for the development of new HFE paradigms, theories, and methodologies to address the ever-increasing complexity of human–system interactions. This scaling out of HFE interests and applications will also require a parallel expansion of human-centered design knowledge for the understanding of emergent behaviors of service systems because of their inherent complexity.

Applications of theories of complex adaptive and dynamical systems are needed to successfully address many of the HFE complex human–systems integration problems, including the fundamental understanding required for modeling and simulation of human, social, economic, environmental, and cultural aspects of work systems, living areas, and the use of smart systems and smart consumer products (Ahram, Karwowski, & Amaba, 2011; Rouse, 2007). To adequately address the challenges for human-centered design of contemporary technological and service systems, researchers should develop complementary paradigms for managing complex and nonlinear human–technology–environment interactions. The HFE discipline should benefit from the adaptation of knowledge of complex adaptive systems, emergent behaviors, dynamics of self-organization in technological and organizational systems, nonlinearity, and chaotic behaviors of human–system interactions. A good example of the critical importance of the theory of complex adaptive systems to HFE is the field of safety engineering.

sec.title: Complexity, System Control, and System Safety
sec.p: Despite the enormous progress in engineering science and design that was made in the past century as well as recent developments in information technology, management of many of the contemporary industrial and service systems, such as mining, oil and gas exploration, nuclear power generation, transportation (including aviation), or health care, continues to be a major challenge for the global society with respect to the safety and health of people who are involved with their daily operation and maintenance as well as the safety and health of customers or clients (e.g., patients) and citizens. Although several engineering, technological, organizational, management, human, social, behavioral, legal, cultural, and other factors contribute to this challenge, it is the interactions of such factors that lead to the increasing complexity of these systems and manifest in unpredictable and unwanted behaviors. Examples of such behaviors often result in the loss of human life and/or the high potential for ecological, economic, social, and environmental damages, including recent disasters in the oil exploration industry (e.g., the BP–Deepwater Horizon oil spill accident, April 2010), in the mining industry (e.g., the Upper Big Branch Mine disaster, April 2010), or in the energy sector (e.g., the recent Fukushima nuclear power plant accident in Japan, April 2011).

As noted by Wulf (2000), “we are increasingly building engineered systems that, because of their inherent complexity, have the potential for behaviors that are impossible to predict in advance” (p. 8). To improve the ability to prevent disasters from occurring again and to mitigate their unwanted consequences in the future, one needs to gain a fundamental understanding of the emergent properties that result from the intricate interactions of the complex system’s components, including the humans in those systems. An emergent system behavior typically occurs when a number of simple entities (agents) operate in an environment, forming more complex behaviors as a collective (Camazine, Deneubourg, Franks, & Sneyd, 2003). For example, as postulated by Plsek and Greenhalgh (2001), to cope with the escalating complexity in health care, one must abandon linear models, accept unpredictability, respect (and use) autonomy and creativity, and respond flexibly to emerging patterns and opportunities. Clearly, better understanding of adaptive and emergent behaviors of complex human–system interactions is of paramount importance to improving the ability to develop better strategies, methodologies, and techniques to improve workplace safety and efficiency in service industries, which is critical to the economic and social well-being of the U.S. economy and the global society at large.

Almost three decades ago, Perrow (1984) proposed that all accidents be viewed as “normal” events in the sense that, given the complexity of system characteristics, multiple and unexpected interactions of failures are inevitable. Such failures should be treated as expression of the integral characteristics of a system and not a statement of frequency. In this view, the system interactions not only are unexpected but also may be incomprehensible for some critical period of time. The theoretical basis for understanding the limitations of the present approach to occupational safety and health and related management solutions, even those that are most advanced technologically, has been outlined as early as in 1956 by Ashby in his paper titled “Requisite Variety and Its Implications for the Control of Complex Systems.” According to Ashby’s (1956) law of requisite variety, a model system or controller can model or control something only to the extent that it has sufficient internal variety to represent it. In general, the larger the variety of actions available to a control system, the larger the variety of perturbations it is able to compensate. In this context, the ability to develop and implement an efficient safety management system (e.g., safety regulator) will depend on one’s understanding of the managed (regulated or controlled) technological or service system’s complexity.

HFE practitioners need to explore the critical science and engineering questions related to future research challenges for the identification of new risks emerging out of the complexity of service and manufacturing industries in the 21st century. The science of complex adaptive systems can be very useful in improving understanding of safety and health issues across a variety of application domains and perhaps even guiding the development of relevant U.S. public policies in this regard. In the aforementioned context, the human–technology– environment interactions that comprise the dynamic configurations of people, technology, and shared information can be investigated as evolving multiagent systems of systems, in which the safety and health risks can be conceptualized as emergent behaviors of evolving adaptive systems. These emergent properties of many contemporary technological and service systems, which may manifest themselves in unexpected and harmful behaviors (i.e., near misses or accidents), represent the most significant challenge to safety engineering and management today.

sec.title: Emergence and Self-Organization
sec.p: Complex human work systems often exhibit emergent global behaviors that are not predictable from their local properties. In the context of HFE problems, global behavior cannot be explicitly described by the behavior of the component systems, and therefore, it may be unpredictable and remain unexpected to designers, system users, or operators, leading to unrecognizable states that are often defined as system errors or aberrations that lead to degraded human performance, industrial accidents, system failures, and catastrophic losses (Dekker, 2011; Rouse, 2000, 2007).

An emergent system behavior (or emergent system property) is present when a number of simple entities (agents) operate in an environment, forming more complex behaviors as a group (Holland, 1988; Hsu & Butterfield, 2009; Stacey, 2005). Cilliers (1998) explained self-organization from the biological perspective and noted that a system not only must receive, process, and retain information, but it also must respond and produce some form of output as well. This process can result in a form of internal structure that is the result of complex interactions between the environment and the system’s history and present state. Examples of emergent behaviors of biological systems include large collectives of independent agents that act as one, including crickets synchronizing their mating calls, seasonal birds flying in large groups, or ant colonies involved in coordinated foraging (Johnson, 2006). Emergent behavior of complex adaptive systems evolves through networked interactions of their constituent subsystems. Such emergent system properties may include everything from traffic jams to the human mind (Stacey, 2005).

Emergent behaviors are often related to the process of self-regulation (Bak & Chen, 1991; Holland, 1988). Self-organization in biological systems is a process in which the pattern at the global level of a system emerges solely from numerous interactions among the lower-level components of the system (Haken, 2000). Furthermore, through the process of self-organization, the internal organization (an open system) increases in complexity without being guided or managed by an outside source (Gleick, 1987). The rules specifying interactions among the system’s components are executed with only local information, without any reference to the global pattern (Ashby, 1947; Camazine et al., 2003). The nonlinear dynamical systems and management of emergent properties in the context of behavioral sciences has recently been discussed in a comprehensive way by Guastello and colleagues (Guastello & Gregson, 2011; Guastello, Koopmans, & Picus, 2009).

sec.title: Chaos: Nonlinear Systems Dynamics
sec.p: A critical factor in understanding behavior of human–systems interactions in many of the contemporary complex technological and service systems is the phenomenon of dynamical instability discovered by Poincaré in 1900 (see Erdi, 2010). In this phenomenon, two nearly indistinguishable sets of initial conditions for the same system may result in two final states or behaviors that differ vastly from each other. The classical laws of Newton’s physics assume the complete connection between cause and effect in nature, with the assumption that for any given system, the same initial conditions should always lead to identical outcomes. However, as noted by Henri Poincaré, such an assumption does not hold for many of the real systems (Erdi, 2010; Lorenz, 1993). This phenomenon also invalidates the underlying assumption that it is always possible to make accurate long-term predictions about any physical system (including human systems) as long as the starting conditions are well defined. This extreme sensitivity to initial conditions is called dynamical instability, or deterministic chaos (Gros, 2008; Waldrop, 1992).
The aforementioned phenomenon can be illustrated with the Mandelbrot fractal set (Mandelbrot, 1982) as the nonlinear function, defined recursively as

After calculating f(x) with values of x several times, the developed set is equal to all of the expressions that are generated. A time series of the set f(x) are plots for a specific value of c, and when c = −1.1, −1.3, and −1.38, such a time series can be expressed as a normal (deterministic) mathematical function. However, when c = −1.9, the function is chaotic and the resulting time series cannot be expressed as a normal function (for more explanation, see http://www.tnellen.com/alt/chaos.html).

According to Gleick (1987), the nonlinear dynamical (chaotic) system behavior is much more widespread and may even be the norm in the universe. Such nonlinear behaviors have been observed in many real systems, where even the smallest discrepancy between two sets of initial conditions can result in a large discrepancy of system responses at later times (Lorenz, 1993). Such deterministic chaos can be found in both simple (the pendulum) and complex systems, including electric circuits, fluid flow, changes in animal populations, disease outbreaks, circadian rhythms, or human electrical brain activity (Gleick, 1987; Waldrop, 1992). Clearly, more quantitative research efforts are needed for one to gain a better understanding of the effects of the aforementioned phenomena in the field of HFE, including human perceptual, physical, and cognitive performance when interacting with complex technologies from the engineering, behavioral, physiological, or neuroscience perspective (Dekker, 2011; Guastello & Gregson, 2011; Walker et al., 2010).

sec.title: Theory of Complex Adaptive Systems: An Overview of Research
sec.p: The use of theories of complex adaptive systems and nonlinear dynamics as a research framework in science, economics, engineering, medicine, and specifically, HFE, has been steadily increasing in the past 20 years. Table 1 provides an overview of selected applications of theory of complex adaptive systems with some representative references.

caption.p: Domains of Application of Theory of Complex Adaptive Systems

tr.td: Lorenz (1993); Hurst & Zimmerman (1994); Camazine, Deneubourg, Franks, & Sneyd (2003)
Glass (1996); Kely & Allison (1999); Stacey (2002); Meek, De Lauduranty, & Howell (2007)
Lipsitz & Goldberger (1992); Goldberger (1996); Rouse (2000); Goldberger, Penga, & Lipsit (2002); Simmons (2003)
Zimmerman, Lindberg, & Plsek (1998); Griffiths & Byrne (1998); Plsek & Greenhalgh (2001); Wilson & Holt (2001); Rouse (2007); Mick & Wyttenback (2003)
Rouse, Cannon-Bowers, & Salas (1992); Karwowski, Marek, & Noworol (1994); Guastello (1995, 2000); Hsu & Butterfield (2009)
Gott (2005); Kallinikos (2005); Galara (2006); Papakostas et al. (2009)
Guzzetti et al. (1996); Mick & Wyttenback (2003); Holden (2005); Ellis (2010)
Karwowski (1993); Karwowski & Marras (1993); Dingwell & Cusumano (2000); Stergiou (2001); Herman (2005); Rodrick & Karwowski (2006); Gielo-Perczak, Karwowski, & Rodrick (2009)
Karwowski (1992a, 1992b); Dooley (1997); Anderson (1999); Stacey (2001, 2005); Gorman, Amazeen, & Cooke (2010), Gorman, Cooke, & Salas (2010); Gorman, Hessler, Amazeen, Cooke, & Shope (2012)

Guastello (1995, 2000); Heath (2000); Tschacher & Dauwalder (2003); Jenkins, Stanton, Walker, Salmon, & Young (2008); Guastello, Koopmans, & Picus (2009); Walker et al. (2009); Guastello (2010); Gorman, Amazeen, et al. (2010); Gorman, Cooke, et al. (2010); Sharma & Ivancevic (2010); Guastello & Gregson (2011)
Rijpma (1997); Gillespie, Robards, & Cho (2004); Wolf and Sampson (2007); Dekker (2011)
Goldberger, Rigney, & West (1990); Rouse et al. (1992); Rouse (2003, 2007, 2008); Banerjee, Rondoni, & Mitra (2011)
Eve et al. (1997); Axelrod (1997); Byrne (1998); Helbing (2012)

sec.p: Recently, Walker et al. (2010) have offered useful overview and interpretation of the main concepts of complexity theory in reference to the scope of HFE. Understandably, such an introduction was mainly of qualitative nature and without references to the rigorous mathematical foundations and modeling frameworks of complexity and adaptive dynamical systems theories (see, for example, quantitative treatment of these theories by Kaplan and Glass, 1995; Haken, 2000; Gros, 2008; or most recently, a primer on complexity by Erdi, 2010).

It should be noted that dynamical instability of complex system behavior in time can also be incorrectly perceived, accepted, and treated as random “noise” or some type of experimental or observational “anomaly” to be discarded. Those in the field of HFE know of many such instances in which current knowledge based on linearity assumptions related to human physical or cognitive performance is not always sufficient for adequate understanding of the underlying human–system behaviors. A few examples of the importance of understanding the potential chaotic behavior related to human physical performance are discussed later.

sec.title: Chaos and Measurement of Human Physical Strength
sec.p: Many of the complex human responses at work exhibit nonlinear properties whereby small changes in the initial task conditions can lead to large changes in system behavior (Guastello, 1995; Karwowski, 2000). This nonlinearity is an important phenomenon that should be more carefully studied for one to gain a better understanding of human performance in a variety of physical and cognitive tasks. Nonlinear dynamics can be used to examine the inherent variability in human motor performance that occurs across multiple repetitions of a task, including variability of human muscular activities (Amato, 1992; Stergiou, Buzzi, Kurz, & Heidel, 2004).

On the basis of evidence from published research in HFE and related fields of medicine, science, and engineering, it can be postulated that many complex human systems or their interacting components and interactions may indeed exhibit high sensitivity to initial conditions that can lead to chaotic system behaviors. Today, such behaviors would typically be treated as anomalies or system aberrations (or unwanted events), as they do not fit the static and linear view of the many concepts that are widely accepted in HFE theory and practice.

For illustration purposes, consider the classical method for human strength measurement. Chaffin and Park (1973) found strength to be an important indicator of low-back pain risk. It was also found in their study that back pain incidence was 3 times greater among those workers who did not have the strength to perform a job. Standard human strength measurement protocol excludes differences in observed strength values greater than 10% (Chaffin, Anderson, & Martin, 1999; Chaffin, Herrin, & Keyserlin, 1978). The important question that should be asked is whether the human posture during the strength measurement process can be replicated exactly (Sparto, Parnianpour, Reinsel, & Simon, 1997). If the answer is no, then is it possible and important to know whether the very small changes in the initial conditions attributed to posture (i.e., slight differences in human body geometry) can lead to larger differences in measured strength capabilities (either greater or smaller values) than those that would be accepted with the standard measurement method. The importance and impact of the possibility that human strength exhibits nonlinearity (with respect to posture and time) cannot be overstated, especially in view of the application of human strength data for developing workplace design guidelines widely used in industry to prevent fatigue and musculoskeletal overexertion injury (Hidalgo et al., 1997; Marras, 2000; Stuebbe et al., 2002). Furthermore, the postulated sensitivity to initial body posture and task conditions (see Figure 1) can be an important factor to consider when validating a conceptual model of the risk factors and lower-back pain (National Research Council & Institute of Medicine, 2001).

caption.p: Illustration of sensitivity to initial conditions attributed to “negligible” differences in posture (P) for isometric strength measures (F).

sec.title: Nonlinear Dynamics of Human Physical Performance
sec.p: As discussed earlier, the essence of chaotic systems is their sensitive dependence of the trajectory on the initial conditions (Cramer, 1993). For example, many human responses to work, such as physiological indices of physical performance (Dingwell & Cusumano, 2000; Gupta, Suryanarayanan, & Reddy, 1997) or measures of situation awareness (Sharma & Ivancevic, 2010), can be described as complex, nonstationary, nonlinear systems that cannot be generated by predictable periodic phenomena. Whereas any deterministic system is predictable on a short time scale, chaotic systems are not predictable on a long time horizon since their behavior is irregular and depends only on the uncertainty of the initial system conditions (Kleeman, 2011).

sec.title: Mathematical Indices of Chaotic Human System Behavior
sec.p: Recent developments in nonlinear dynamics and chaos have provided new theoretical and conceptual tools that allow for capturing and understanding complex behavior of physical performance. In general, two quantitative measures, namely, Lyapunov exponent (LE) and Kolmogorov entropy, can be used to study the dynamics (time dependence) of chaotic behavior and provide information about how the system evolves over time (Hilborn, 2000). The largest LE quantifies chaoticity in the dominant phase-space direction and may be regarded as an estimator of dominant chaoticity, whereas the Kolmogorov entropy represents a measure of overall chaoticity (Kaplan & Glass, 1995; Pesin, 1977).

A quantitative measure of the sensitive dependence on the initial conditions is the LE (Erdi, 2010; Gros, 2008). LE is defined as the average rate of divergence (or convergence) of two neighboring trajectories. The number of LEs is equal to the dimension of the phase space (Stefanski, 2000). Lyapunov number (LN) is the average per-step divergence rate of nearby points along the orbit. LE is the natural log of LN. The largest LE determines the prediction horizon of system behavior. Chaos is determined by at least one positive LE. Accordingly, deterministic chaos can be defined as the rate of divergence in system behavior (trajectories) and can be expressed by the largest positive LE (Abarbanel, Brown, & Kennel, 1991).

sec.title: Example 1: Chaos in Electromyographical Manifestation of Muscular Exertions
sec.p: Rodrick and Karwowski (2006) explored nonlinear characteristics of the surface myoelectrical (EMG) activity of the biceps muscle during simulated maximum voluntary contraction (MVC) at a reference arm posture (MVCRP) and at an elevated static arm work posture (EAWP) observed on the manufacturing assembly line. Nonlinear dynamics analysis proposed by Hilborn (2000), Stergiou (2001), and Kaplan and Glass (1995) was used to analyze the time series data. The state space was reconstructed with two steps: estimation of time delay estimation and estimation of minimum embedding dimensions. For time delay estimation, each EMG signal is represented as a scalar time series. To estimate time delay, Rodrick and Karwowski used the average mutual information method with the first minimum selected as the time delay. They estimated the minimum embedding dimension of the EMG signals by using Cao’s (1997) method. An illustration of phase-space reconstruction for EMG activity of the erector spinae muscle is shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: Illustration of 3-D phase-space reconstruction used to determine evidence of chaos in electro-myogram signal for erector spinae muscle in lifting condition.

sec.p: The study results showed that positive LEs existed for each of the trials in both work postures. Surface EMG of the biceps brachii was more chaotic in the MVCRP condition as compared with the EAWP condition. On the basis of the Kaplan-Yorke dimension, it was observed that the recorded two types of time series EMG data were similar in complexity. The study’s authors also found a significant difference in fractal dimensions between the two postures. It was concluded that the nonlinear dynamical EMG properties expressed in terms of the LE, Kaplan-Yorke dimension, and fractal dimensions could be used as useful indices for evaluation of the level of muscular efforts in static work conditions.

Evidence of chaos in muscular exertions based on EMG time series analysis measured at MVC level signifies the importance of predictability of human exertions and muscular system responses to complex task and work demands. Given such chaotic behavior, one of the important questions is, Should human strength be used as a task design criterion? More generally, the aforementioned preliminary results indicate a need for improved understanding of the complexity of human muscular performance and muscular system at work in general. In addition, one should ask whether the human musculoskeletal system’s states while performing physical tasks and its responses are deterministic and predictable. Are there any unstable steady states? What are the effects of nonlinear properties of human muscular activity on the processes of muscle coactivation or fatigue? Furthermore, the nonlinear dynamical EMG properties may be used as sensitive indices of the level of muscular activity and, potentially, muscular overexertion. Nonlinear dynamics analysis of EMG may also allow supplementing conventional methods intended to identify and explain the mechanisms of muscular fatigue. Finally, it is suggested that researchers explore the following plausible hypothesis that relates nonlinearity of human muscular exertion and musculoskeletal injury prevention: Work-related injury pathways may exhibit chaotic behavior related to nonlinear dynamics of the human musculoskeletal system in response to seemingly “negligible,” but critical, changes in the initial conditions of the broadly defined work system space as specified by the task demands and/or subject characteristics.

sec.title: Example 2: Dynamics of Postural Balance While Working on Heights
sec.p: Gielo-Perczak, Karwowski, and Rodrick (2009) investigated nonlinear characteristics of human biomechanical responses while participants were working at elevated construction sites. Specifically, the study focused on the center of pressure (COP) at foot level observed while participants were standing on a beam when working at simulated construction heights in different hand loading conditions. The effects of beam width on dynamics of human postural balance in controlled conditions of standardized foot placement on a beam, single-hand load holding on the side in either left or right hand, and different step lengths were investigated. The beam size and foot location were as follows: 10 cm beam-forward (left) foot, 10 cm beam-backward (right) foot, 22.5 cm beam-forward (left) foot, and 22.5 cm beam-backward (right) foot. The load was held in a single hand, with five conditions as follows: no load, 6.8 kg left hand, 6.8 kg right hand, 11.3 kg left hand, and 11.3 kg right hand. Finally, step length, that is, foot separation (short and long step), was also controlled.

ANOVA was used to analyze differences in the largest positive LEs for the measured COP in various experimental conditions. The results showed that standing on the narrow beam resulted in a higher level of chaotic behavior, measured by positive LEs for COP, compared with the wide-beam condition. The nonlinearity of COP exerted by the forward (left) leg was higher for the narrow-beam condition. For both beams, the nonlinearity of COP exerted by the forward (left) foot was consistently higher than the COP exerted by the backward (right) foot. For both beams, single-handed holding of the 11.3-kg load resulted in higher levels of COP nonlinearity than did carrying 6.8 kg or no load at all. Holding a heavy load in one hand increased the nonlinearity of COP regardless of the beam width. The front (left) foot was mostly responsible for the chaotic behavior of the COP while standing on the narrow beam. With the assumption that postural stability can be defined in terms of nonlinear properties of the COP exerted at feet level, the dynamic behavior of the forward foot (left) in the single-handed high-load holding condition may be critical to preserving the postural stability of the construction workers and consequently reduce the risk of falls from heights.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Understanding and modeling complexity and dynamic changes in human–system interactions and related human compatibility requirements will require the application of complex adaptive and dynamical systems approach and methodology. Furthermore, it can also be postulated that human–systems interactions, more often than not, constitute complex adaptive phenomena with emergent properties that can exhibit nonlinear dynamical (chaotic) behaviors. Therefore, application of the science of complex adaptive systems in HFE should significantly improve the effectiveness of human-centered design efforts.

To meet the human needs of the 21st century, modern HFE discipline needs to evolve toward the design and management of complex adaptive human–systems interactions to optimize sustainable human and system performance, increase human–systems resilience, and minimize system life cycle cost. The success of future human–systems integration efforts at the individual human performance level in the sensory, perceptual, physical, and cognitive domains, considered from the neuroscience perspective, as well as technological and service system-of-systems levels, will require fusion of paradigms, knowledge, design principles, and methodologies of HFE with those of the science of complex adaptive systems, nonlinear dynamics, and modern systems engineering.

list-item.p: This article addresses the challenges posed by the inherent properties and behaviors of complex adaptive systems for human factors and ergonomics research in general and human–systems integration in particular.

To improve understanding of the true nature of human–systems interactions and overall system performance, one needs to take into consideration dynamical properties of such interactions, which may be attributable to the inherent complexity of the large number of either relatively simple rules or interdependent interactions between system components.

Human–systems interactions may be very sensitive to small changes in the initial task or operating system conditions, leading to nonlinear, and therefore, often unpredictable—that is, emergent—system responses, which can be critical to assuring system safety and performance efficiency. Examples of recent studies of nonlinear behavior observed in human physical performance were used to illustrate this thesis.

Contemporary work systems and work environments should be considered as complex, dynamic, and adaptive systems with self-organizing properties that can exhibit emergent (unpredictable) human–system interactions and related nonlinear system behaviors.

bio.p: Waldemar Karwowski is a professor and chairman of the Department of Industrial Engineering and Management Systems and the executive director of the Institute for Advanced Systems Engineering at the University of Central Florida, Orlando. He holds an MS (1978) in production engineering and management from the Technical University of Wroclaw, Poland, and a PhD (1982) in industrial engineering from Texas Tech University. He was awarded a DSc (Dr. habil.) degree in management science by the State Institute for Organization and Management in Industry, Poland (2004). He is a past president of the International Ergonomics Association (2000–2003) and a past president of the Human Factors and Ergonomics Society (2007). He served on the Committee on Human Factors/Human Systems Integration, National Research Council, the National Academies (2007–2011). He is the author or coauthor of more than 380 scientific publications, which focus on occupational ergonomics, cognitive engineering, activity theory, knowledge management, systems engineering, human–computer interaction, neuro-fuzzy modeling, nonlinear dynamics in human performance, and neuroergonomics.
